style="background: #E0E7EF;" colspan="2" | Championship Success |- | colspan="2"|'''[[List of Super Bowl champions|Super Bowl Championships]] (7)''' *'''PIT''' (6) – [[Super Bowl IX|1974]], [[Super Bowl X|1975]], [[Super Bowl XIII|1978]], [[Super Bowl XIV|1979]], [[Super Bowl XL|2005]], [[Super Bowl XLIII|2008]] *'''BAL''' (1) – [[Super Bowl XXXV|2000]] '''[[List of National Football League seasons|Conference Championships]] (9)''' *'''PIT''' (8) – [[1974 NFL season|1974]], [[1975 NFL season|1975]], [[1978 NFL season|1978]], [[1979 NFL season|1979]], [[1995 NFL season|1995]], [[2005 NFL season|2005]], [[2008 NFL season|2008]], [[2010 NFL season|2010]] *'''BAL''' (1) – [[2000 NFL season|2000]] '''[[AFC North|Divisional Championships]] (22)''' *'''PIT''' (20) – [[1972 NFL season|1972]], [[1974 NFL season|1974]], [[1975 NFL season|1975]], [[1976 NFL season|1976]], [[1977 NFL season|1977]], [[1978 NFL season|1978]], [[1979 NFL season|1979]], [[1983 NFL season|1983]], [[1984 NFL season|1984]], [[1992 NFL season|1992]], [[1994 NFL season|1994]], [[1995 NFL season|1995]], [[1996 NFL season|1996]], [[1997 NFL season|1997]], [[2001 NFL season|2001]], [[2002 NFL season|2002]], [[2004 NFL season|2004]], [[2007 NFL season|2007]], [[2008 NFL season|2008]], [[2010 NFL season|2010]] *'''BAL''' (2) – [[2003 NFL season|2003]], [[2006 NFL season|2006]] |} The rivalry between the '''[[Baltimore Ravens]]''' and the '''[[Pittsburgh Steelers]]''' is one of the most intense in the [[National Football League]]. Both teams are members of the AFC North division, and play at least twice a year in what are often battles for divisional supremacy. Both teams are known for fielding tough, hard-hitting defensive squads, giving their games an extra element of physical intensity. The two teams have met in the postseason three times, all resulting in Steelers wins. They are the only two teams in the [[AFC North]] to have won the [[Super Bowl]], and possess a combined 7-2 record in the game. ==History== In 1996, NFL football returned to [[Baltimore]], 12 years after the original [[Indianapolis Colts|Baltimore Colts]] [[Baltimore Colts relocation controversy|moved]] to [[Indianapolis]]. In a strange twist of fate, [[Art Modell]] relocated his Central Division team to Baltimore. The inter-divisional rivalry carried over with both teams remaining in what was then the AFC's Central Division. Since the formation of the AFC North in 2002, the Steelers and Ravens have dominated the division, with the Steelers winning or tying for six divisional titles (as of 2010) and the Ravens taking two however, the Ravens did clinch a playoff spot in 2009 as a [[Wild card (sports)|wild-card]] as the Steelers barely missed the playoffs.) Sports Illustrated has ranked the rivalry #2 on a list of "Top 10 New NFL Rivalries." [http://images.si.com/multimedia/photo_gallery/2005/12/15/gallery.newrivals/content.9.html Images.si.com] {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#b0c4de; width:20em;" cellspacing="5" | style="text-align: left;" |"The coaches hate each other, the players hate each other... There's no calling each other after the game and inviting each other out to dinner. But the feeling's mutual: They don't like us, and we don't like them. There's no need to hide it, they know it, and we know it. It's going to be one of those black and blue games."''[http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/06327/740767-66.stm Post-Gazette.com] |- | style="text-align: right;" | ~- Steelers WR '''[[Hines Ward]]''' |} It is currently the top rivalry for both teams{{fact|date=June 2011}}. In Baltimore, it has the added element of a small number of former Colts fans in the area becoming [[Steeler Nation|Steeler fans]] after the Colts moved, then retaining their affiliation with the Steelers after the Ravens moved to Baltimore and assumed the [[Cleveland Browns]]' spot in the [[AFC North|AFC Central]] with the Steelers. In [[Pittsburgh]], it is considered the [[spiritual successor]] to the [[BrownsâSteelers rivalry]] due to the [[Cleveland Browns relocation controversy]] as well as the "reactivated" [[Cleveland Browns]] having a 4-21 record against the Steelers since returning to the league in 1999.http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/playoffs2008/columns/story?columnist=garber_greg&page=HotRead18/Ravens-Steelers Due to its physical nature, it has received comparisons to the rivalry the Steelers had with the [[Oakland Raiders]] in the 1970's, when those two teams were among the most physical teams in the league.http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/09016/942193-66.stm The two teams are so similar in style that they have received comparisons to each other in a similar matter to that of the [[Mirror, Mirror (Star Trek: The Original Series)|Mirror, Mirror]] episode of ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series]]''.[http://www.steelerstoday.com/?p=7082 It's Ravens week|Steelers Today - A Pittsburgh Steelers Blog] Since the Steelers introduced their [[throwback uniform]] as their [[third jersey|alternate uniform]] in 2007, they have used one of their two annual allotted games with the uniform against the Ravens at home three times, signifying the significance of the rivalry. The Ravens have typically worn their regular uniforms at home against the Steelers instead of their all-black third uniform. Some memorable moments in the rivalry have included Ravens Linebacker [[Terrell Suggs]] being quoted as saying that a "bounty" was put out on the head of Steelers Wide Receiver [[Hines Ward]]. The bounty controversy was cleared up when Suggs insisted his words were just meant as a joke. The NFL investigated and Suggs was cleared of any wrong doing. The rivalry reached a new height of intensity during the [[2008 NFL season]], when the Steelers and Ravens played three times, the last match being the AFC Championship. The Steelers won all three games, by close margins. The margins were so close that in the regular season just under two yards would have shifted from a Steelers sweep to a Ravens sweep. In week 15, the Steelers won with a controversial score late in the game. In the playoff game, a personal foul by the special teams player [[Daren Stone]] cost the Ravens 25 yards. The last play was an interception that was returned for a touchdown by Troy Polamalu. In that same game the Steelers' [[Ryan Clark]] delivered a controversial hit on the Ravens' [[Willis McGahee]] that left Clark briefly out cold and forced McGahee to spend the night in a Pittsburgh hospital. The Rivalry continued in the 2009 season. Both the Steelers and the Ravens went 9-7, but Baltimore won a wild-card slot due to a better division record . Baltimore won the Wild-Card game by defeating the [[New England Patriots]] 33â14, but lost to the [[Indianapolis Colts]] the following game. In 2010, Steelers head coach [[Mike Tomlin]] called the SteelersâRavens rivalry the best rivalry in football during a press conference and on the [[ESPN]] show ''[[Pardon the Interruption]]''. Ravens head coach [[John Harbaugh]] later agreed with this assessment. On opening day of the 2011 season, the Ravens forced 7 turnovers and routed the Steelers 35-7 at M&T Bank Stadiumhttp://www.steelers.com/news/article-1/A-true-rivalry/a5c43f81-f340-452f-a2ff-7cdd45c5ebe4 A notable battleground for the rivalry is the [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania]] market area. Harrisburg is officially a secondary market for the Ravens, and so [[WHP-TV]] must show all Ravens road games (if played on Sunday afternoon). The Steelers also have a significant fanbase in the area, so when the Ravens are at home, the Steelers are shown instead. ==Game results== The following is a list of results from all of the meetings between the '''Baltimore Ravens''' and '''Pittsburgh Steelers''' from their first meeting on September 8, 1996 to the present: {| class="wikitable" |bgcolor="#CCFFFF"|'''[[NFL playoffs|Post Season Meeting]]''' |bgcolor="#FFE6BD"|'''[[Overtime (sports)|Overtime Result]]''' |} ===1990s (Steelers 6-2)=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- !Year !width="10%"| Date !width="12%"| Winner !Result !width="12%"| Loser !width="13%"|Location !Notes |- |rowspan="2" | [[1996 National Football League season|1996]] |September 8 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|31–17 |Baltimore Ravens |[[Three Rivers Stadium]] | |- |December 1 |'''Baltimore Ravens''' |align="center"|31–17 |Pittsburgh Steelers |[[Memorial Stadium (Baltimore)|Memorial Stadium]] | |- |rowspan="2" | [[1997 National Football League season|1997]] |October 5 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|42–34 |Baltimore Ravens |Memorial Stadium | |- |- |November 9 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|37–0 |Baltimore Ravens |Three Rivers Stadium |First season sweep by either team and largest margin of defeat in series history. |- |rowspan="2" | [[1998 National Football League season|1998]] |September 23 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|20–13 |Baltimore Ravens |[[M&T Bank Stadium]] |First loss for Ravens at M&T Bank Stadium. |- |- |October 18 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|16–6 |Baltimore Ravens |Three Rivers Stadium | |- |rowspan="2" | [[1999 National Football League season|1999]] |September 19 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|23–20 |Baltimore Ravens |M&T Bank Stadium | |- |December 12 |'''Baltimore Ravens''' |align="center"|31–24 |Pittsburgh Steelers |Three Rivers Stadium |First win for Ravens in Pittsburgh. Ravens wide receiver [[Qadry Ismail]] scored three touchdowns (all at least 54 yards) with 258 receiving yards, the all-time record at Three Rivers Stadium.http://www.chicagotribune.com/topic/bal-sp.lookback26sep26,0,4703680.story |- |} ===2000s (Steelers 13-9)=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- !Year !width="10%"| Date !width="12%"| Winner !Result !width="12%"| Loser !width="13%"|Location !Notes |- |rowspan="2" | [[2000 National Football League season|2000]] |September 3 |'''Baltimore Ravens''' |align="center"|16–0 |Pittsburgh Steelers |Three Rivers Stadium | |- |- |October 29 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|9–6 |Baltimore Ravens |M&T Bank Stadium |Last loss for the Raven for the remainder of the season, en route to the team's victory in [[Super Bowl XXXV]]. |- |rowspan="3" | [[2001 National Football League season|2001]] |November 4 |'''Baltimore Ravens''' |align="center"|13–10 |Pittsburgh Steelers |[[Heinz Field]] |First loss for Steelers at Heinz Field. |- |- |October 16 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|26–21 |Baltimore Ravens |M&T Bank Stadium | |- |- bgcolor="#CCFFFF" |January 20, 2002 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|27–10 |Baltimore Ravens |Heinz Field |AFC Divisional Playoff. The first playoff game between the Ravens and Steelers. |- |rowspan="2" | [[2002 National Football League season|2002]] |October 27 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|31–18 |Baltimore Ravens |M&T Bank Stadium | |- |December 29 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|34–31 |Baltimore Ravens |Heinz Field | |- |rowspan="2" | [[2003 National Football League season|2003]] |September 7 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|34–15 |Baltimore Ravens |Heinz Field | |- |December 28 |'''Baltimore Ravens''' |align="center"|13–10 |Baltimore Ravens |M&T Bank Stadium | |- |rowspan="2" | [[2004 National Football League season|2004]] |September 19 |'''Baltimore Ravens''' |align="center"|30–13 |Pittsburgh Steelers |M&T Bank Stadium |Ravens wore white jerseys against Steelers in home opener. The first AFC Championship game between the Ravens and Steelers (Steelers 2-0 in playoffs vs Ravens). |- |rowspan="2" | [[2009 National Football League season|2009]] |bgcolor="#FFE6BD"|November 29 |bgcolor="#FFE6BD"|'''Baltimore Ravens''' |align="center" bgcolor="#FFE6BD"|20–17 '''(OT)''' |bgcolor="#FFE6BD"|Pittsburgh Steelers |bgcolor="#FFE6BD"|M&T Bank Stadium | |- |December 27 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|23–20 |Baltimore Ravens |Heinz Field | |- |} ===2010s (Ravens 3-2)=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- !Year !width="10%"| Date !width="12%"| Winner !Result !width="12%"| Loser !width="13%"|Location !Notes |- |rowspan="3" | [[2010 NFL season|2010]] |October 3 |'''Baltimore Ravens''' |align="center"|17–14 |Pittsburgh Steelers |Heinz Field | |- |December 5 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|13–10 |Baltimore Ravens |M&T Bank Stadium | |- |- bgcolor="#CCFFFF" |January 15, 2011 |'''Pittsburgh Steelers''' |align="center"|31–24 |Baltimore Ravens |Heinz Field |AFC Divisional Playoff. Steelers remain undefeated in the playoffs against the Ravens (3-0). |- |rowspan="2" | [[2011 National Football League season|2011]] |September 11 |'''Baltimore Ravens''' |align="center"|35–7 |Pittsburgh Steelers |[[M&T Bank Stadium]] | |- |November 6 |'''Baltimore Ravens''' |align="center"|23–20 |Pittsburgh Steelers |[[Heinz Field]] | |- |} ==See also== *[http://www.afc-north.com/rivalry/pitbal.html AFC-north.com] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite web|first=Damon|last=Hick|title=Adapt Or Die: Infusing new blood into the league's fiercest rivalry, the Ravens demolished the Steelers and changed the balance of power in the AFC. Evolution? In the NFL, you'd better believe|date=September 19, 2011|publisher=Sports Illustrated|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1190450/index.htm|accessdate=2011-11-23}} {{Navboxes|list1= {{Baltimore Ravens}} {{Pittsburgh Steelers}} {{NFL rivalries}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:SteelersâRavens Rivalry}} [[Category:Baltimore Ravens]] [[Category:Pittsburgh Steelers]] [[Category:National Football League rivalries]]
